Ok, so now that Starship has "advanced" its development, are there any arguments remaining for using steel? The dry mass of Starship is ridiculous. The HLLV from NASA's SPS study had a similar payload to Starship, yet only 4000t weight when fully fueled (lese than simply the fuel mass of Starship!) - even with some mass reserve! Apparently, aluminium construction/winged flyback is a pretty efficient design! From what I can gather, the SPS HLLV has enough of a mass margin that it can afford to have a heatshield separate from the cryotanks, with an insulation layer in between. Most of the heat is blocked out by the tiles and insulation, and so the actual temperature affecting exterior of the tanks should be no worse than the rocket standing in summer sun. So not a 2500°C difference but only about 300°C - much better. So it goes 2500°C frontface -> heat tiles -> 100-300°C backface -> insulation -> -300°C tank interior. By splitting the load, you can also optimize the thermal systems - the tiles for high temperatures to medium ones, the insulation from medium to low ones. In addition, Starship absolutely needs a thick TPS, no matter the material - its tanks also serve as the outer hull, so the tiles have to handle the entire 2500°C -> -200°C jump by themselves, the high melting point of steel doesn't matter. It would matter if the tanks were separate from the hull and it used a variation of the "hot structure" system proposed for the Dyna-Soar project, but Starship isn't built like that. There is a good point about the fatigue, but it isn't really tested - long-term wear and tear isn't really easy to predict. It could end up having higher maintenance needs than an aluminium construction, we can't know for sure until it is tested in actual conditions.
P. S. Plus, the heavy steel construction forces Starship to use baloon tanks, like the Atlas I/II - and everybody will tell you that rocket was incredibly difficult to handle and move around, since the structure tended to crumple and buckle at the slightest loads, and even collapsed if it lost tank pressure. And despite baloon tanks being one of the lightest tank constructions ever known, Starship is still incredibly heavy. So another hit against steel.

Oct 14th 2021l now, and I think SpaceX could do a ton of launches of propellant tanks, using separate LOX and fuel tankers that are just OBT (one big tank) of either, and which never come back to Earth, but instead form a tank farm in orbit, maybe a highly elliptical one, or whatever, but a very useful payload that decouples the cadence and count of Earth launches from launches to a Lunar orbit - or Mars for that matter.

Why now? Because if the Super Heavy works well enough to lift these, SpaceX does something useful while getting a lot of experience lifting at max weights while working out bugs, and the tank "Starship" is simple, cheap, and yet critical for the Artemis System. This will be very helpful in decoupling the testing of Super Heavy and Starship, in addition to decoupling the cadence of launches. Perhaps NASA could offer SpaceX a fixed price contract for each full tank placed in orbit.

Because there is no reentry, these simple OBT tanker ships might be better made out of aluminum, but maybe experience with the same material as the Lunar Starship is more valuable than the weight of propellant lost to a heavier tanker, whatever. Eventually there may be 3 propellant farms. LOX, Methane, and Kerosene for F9s lifting Crew Dragons to said orbit, allowing F9s to be fully reusable, which would be a nice way for the BFR to help out its little brother, AND put an end to the Orange Money-pit. Once the Lunar Starship is certified for crewed flight the F9s could be retasked, but the Kerosene tank-farm could be moved to a Lunar orbit to feed Merlin engines working in the much lower gravity of the Moon, or continue to make almost all F9 flights fully reusable here on Earth.

@Everyday Astronaut
having a reflective coating is not an advantage in heat management in this case. Black objects not only gain heat faster from radiation, but also lose it faster in the same way. Black objects are believed to heat up faster, but this is because most of the heat comes from the sun and not from other sources. When re-entering the atmosphere, most of the spacecraft's heat comes from friction. And being black is an advantage because a lot of that heat is given off as radiation.
Example: Lockheed SR 71 Blackbird was also heating up to great temperatures, yet it was completely black

Part of the reason simple weight matters less on the Starship is simply it's size. On a rocket, every gram of structure counts, as it adds to the parasitic weight. But the larger the rocket, the less each gram is as a proportion of the total mass. That's no advantage if the hull is twice as thick as well as having twice the height and width, but the hull can be less than twice as thick, so you get a benefit.

Then you have the fact that the Starship is much wider compared to the length of most rockets. The closer a container is to a sphere, the less material it needs to hold a given volume. Rockets are generally long and thin, to reduce air resistance. But the Starship is 9 metres in diameter compared to 3.7 m on Falcon 9, while only being 120 m tall compared to 70 m. So the hull takes less material for the volume.

I believe that one of the reasons why the space shuttle's underbelly/heat shield was black was because it was a more effective black body emitter. X times "cheaper" is not a correct expression, because something being X times in measurement compared to Y implies that X is greater in value. "60 times cheaper" just isn't a correct term when trying to compare things mathematically. Just discovered this channel recently and thought I'd check out some older vids.  I think one the things people tend to get hung up on with Stainless Steel is they don't understand that it's really a blanket term.  For example 300 series Stainless has a lot more precious metals in it, tends to be softer than regular steel (which is good for machining but bad but overall strength), and is extremely rust resistant.  400 series stainless is more like regular steel, it's cheaper/has fewer precious metals, it's almost as hard as regular steel, and it will still rust almost as easily as regular steel (which is the part that really pisses me off since a lot of companies advertise 400 series as stainless, which is technically is, but then the product rust).  Of course things like the thickness of the steel, how it's formed (cold formed as stated in the vid gives stronger properties), and it's shape can all have huge effects on the properties of the finished product.

Well the issue I can see the annealing temperature of 310s stainless, is about 1000c so your going to loose a lot of your strength in the skin on reentry. Issue I can see comparing it to the same type of cooling used in engine bells is that fuel is being used at high rate and then it's used in combustion,  so the additional heat is dumped during combustion. engineering student here: steel is sometimes the better choice for lightweight structures than carbon, aluminum, magnesium & co., as unintuitive as it sounds. When designing for minimum weight, you have to consider many, many properties, density and yield strength are two of them, stiffness (Young's modulus) and fracture toughness are other examples. Additionally, the temperature dependence of each of these properties needs to be considered and calculations made for different operating conditions. Steels (and stainless steels) are very, very well understood and studied materials, because they've been used and abused in the industry for 100+ years, contrary to aluminum and carbon composites. New lightweight materials are great, just keep in mind that everytime their boundaries are explored and pushed further, there's a risk of big failures and, sadly, human lives.
Cold forming occurs at room temperature and not cryogenic temperatures. Hot forming is when you work with nearly molten metal and leaves a pitted surface. Both require presses and rollers.

Hi, Tim.
There's one thing that's been bugging me since the steel starship was presented, with the support that steel resists better to heating and thus needs less protection (less weight in heat-shield)...
It's that, even though a steel frame resists better to the heating, it will still heat up more, specially if there is not as much heat-shielding. What about all that is inside this baking-hot spaceship, like instruments, life-support systems and ultimately, crew and passengers?


In a spacecraft made of aluminium or carbon composites, the thermal ceiling will be at about 300°C, and needs a sturdy heatshield, to avoid damaging the frame and the interior. Well, if a steel frame allows the thermal ceiling to be raised to 800°C or more, that's still much below the plasma-creating temperatures of the surrounding air during re-entry - so, a heat-shield should still be necessary.
This begs two questions: 1st - won't methane cooling of the heatshield heat up the methane to unstable temperatures and expand it drastically due to heating, thus loosing it's thermal conductivity and cooling ability of the heat-shield?
2nd - won't it be difficult to manage overheating of the frame if it's allowed to heat up to 800 degrees or more, mainly because the interior must always be at or below 25 degrees?

You missed one of the core ideas of "hot metal structure": More capability to radiate heat away during reentry, which could bring down reentry temperature significantly. Because of the higher heat conduction rate inside metal structures, the entire frame will keep a more homogenous temperature than otherwise. That means the entire metal structure could radiate heat into the deep space. Since radiation rate is proportional to the surface area, this will let the heat get away vastly faster than the shuttle. A much lower-temperature heat balance state could be achieved. Pairing with a reflective surface and cooling pipes, and an optimized reentry profile, a peak temperature of as low as 1000 celsius is not impossible.

Ok, so first of all, you're awesome. I discovered your channel yesterday and I love it.

I just want to mention a couple material properties that you missed. The first is that steel has amazing fatigue characteristics. They might not come into play in this specific use case, but it makes a huge difference in re-usability.


The second is the reflectivity thing. On re-entry, most of your heat is coming from friction, not radiation. This means that the shiny, reflective surface (low emissivity) won't make a big difference in how much heat gets absorbed. This does mean though that the surface can't dissipate it's heat well using radiation, because having a low emissivity means that you don't absorb much radiant heat, but you also can't dissipate much radiant heat. All of that said, I'd love it if you proved me wrong.

Cheers ;)

A few comments here, after having a conversation with a metallurgist (who just so happens to be my father).

1. The cost of the stainless steel depends upon the alloy used (there are thousands - and they're all very very different), but you're still right - the carbon composite process and cost is prohibitively expensive and time-consuming.
2. Another interesting alloy that is what is used in stainless steel ball bearings, which are typically made from 440C (which is too brittle and can cause failure) were replaced with carburizing stainless steel 675 Stainless (a fascinating topic in itself that got addressed after the challenger disaster)
3. Testability for failure was left out. Carbon composites make detecting flaws (especially in a reusable rocket) a tricky business. When you are working with stainless, the techniques are well-established and test are not particularly expensive to run - which would be a consistent expectation before every new launch. It might be an interesting episode to talk about how certain materials can be tested for things like risk of failure - where small defects can be disastrous.
4. WD-40 will (probably) not be required, or anything like that. But we had a good laugh from the animation about the drones spraying the rocket down - that was pretty funny. 2 points for the space humor.

I don't understand your comment that SS is shiny so that it will "reflect" energy away.  The metal is being heated and is the source of heat, thus it's advantageous to be able to RADIATE the energy away.  In that case, SS is actually a poor radiator because it's shiny.  Being shiny means that it has low emissivity, and high emissivity is what you need to be a good radiator.  We thus need to consider the emissivity of SS as a drawback, and as you say, compromise is often a complicated mix of different considerations.

The main reason SpaceX moved away from carbon composite nanotubes is that the oxidizer leaked into the main fuel tank and being hypergolic cause unwanted explosions under extreme pressure.  This caused the rocket to blow up under the extreme pressure of simply pumping the fuels into the rocket at high pressure just before liftoff.  A material that could expand and compress without leaking fuel to the other chamber while still light enough to not create an enormous weight change was necessary.  Thus, stainless steel became the nest choice without the need to redesign the whole rocket.

I am sort of an expert on cold forming... And the term cold forming is actually when you work on materials at a "normal temperature" and don't naturally add energy to the workpiece. Nothing to do with making a workpiece "cold."

Hot forming is typically called forging, where the goal is to heat a workpiece up and make it easier to arrange atoms and be able to stretch it out. Cold forming we keep it "normal" because we want it to be hard to move because that gives added strength but you cannot move the atoms as far. Cold and hot forming experiences work-hardening and does make the material "stronger", just quicker in cold forming.

Do they make their material colder than the typical cold forming process? Possibly. But that isn't strictly cold forming.

Only yield strength is mentioned while comparing stainless to aluminium to carbon composite. This makes sense, if you're building a structure that'll stay where it's built. When dynamic effects are in place, impact energy is a metric to be considered as well. It basically tells how much energy your material absorbs before fracturing into two parts, and is a good measure of tendency to crack propagation. Room temperature example would be ceramics, which has excellent yield strength and terrible impact energy. Seen any rockets made of ceramics? Low impact energy is why not. Coming back to cryogenic temps, CrNi stainless steels have excellent cryogenic impact energy characteristics compared to almost everything except some other metallic alloys.

https://www.jeremyjordan.me/ductile-to-brittle-transitions-in-materials/ --> stainless is fcc, C-steel is BCC and fiber-reinforced polymers act similar, and ceramics is a good example of high strength. transition temp and absolute value of impact energy will depend on material.

For protecting a stainless steel rocket I think an IHC (industrial hard carbon) coating would be ideal. Creating an application process for something that large could be a challenge but if feasible would produce a very durable coating with excellent wear and corrosion resistance. The cost of the coating material is quite low. The application process would drive the total cost. IHC is most often used in industry to increase the life of critical mechanical components such as gears and bearings and is frequently applied to various types of steel. IHC also has extremely high lubricity which might help slightly reduce atmospheric friction for any exposed sections not covered by heat shield.

There's a big problem with the "Convair used WD-40 to protect the outer skin of the stainless steel Atlas missle from rust" story, as any properly made stainless steel DOESN'T RUST! That's what "stainless" means! I've found sources that say that Convair used WD-40 to protect "rocket parts" from rust, which could mean any of a miriad of small and large parts, possibly in the engines, but unless the skin of the tank was made from a particularly low grade of stainless steel, there would be no reason to coat the skin of the rocket with the stuff.
WD-40 got it's name because it means "Water Displacer, formula #40", not "rust preventer". It's possible Convair might have put a layer on the outside of the missile to help it shed rainwater, basically an early attempt at a Rain-X type substance, but even that doesn't make much sense. WD-40 is composed of light and volatile hydrocarbons. Unlike an oil, WD-40, if left exposed, will evaporate away in a day or two. Unless they had a guy on a ladder out there constantly spraying on new stuff, it would be pointless to use it on large areas of metal that are constantly exposed to wind and sunlight.
The whole point of using a stainless steel is so that you don't need to use any form of conformal coating, or impressed current system, or any other anti-corrosion system, other than the SS itself.

Stainless steel isn't 60 times cheaper. The price of stainless steel is 3$ per kg, but the density is 7.85 g/cc while carbon fiber with epoxy composite have a density of 1.57 g/cc. That means that the carbon fiber with epoxy composite is 5 times lighter and therefore the price per cc goes down, and that is the price that matters since they aren't buying the materials for having them as a paperweight.
So the price for stainless steel is actually 0.02355$ per cc while carbon fiber is 0,2826$ per cc, Therefore stainless steel is 12 times cheaper than carbon fiber.

11 mins into this video: Jet engines keep there internal engine fan blade plates cool by "leaking" coolent onto the outer surface of the engine fan blade plate, with a simular idea of tiny holes that keep a layer of coolent between the hot burning gasses of the engine and the solid metal of the engine blade plate. The comment about the space shuttle tiles soaking up a lot of heat and radiating it later (around 7:50 in the video) is not correct. Those tiles had an extremely high insulation value. That is the reason why they can be picked up with bear fingers. The material itself has actually taken on a very low amount of energy. When touched by fingers, the energy in the area of the contact points is so low that the skin quickly absorbs it. As the same time, the heat in the rest of the tile (which is still not very much) is so badly conducted, that it hardly flows to the contact areas. Hence: no burns.

The entire idea of rockets as they've been being built for many decades is stupid.

The way to do it is blimps. Blimps would revolutionize mars exploration as well. Here's how:

You have a plane that is a specially designed flying wing similar to a stealth bomber take off from any airport. This plane would be equipped with regular jet engines to achieve around 40,000 feet altitude.

Once at 40k, this plane lands on a blimp type aircraft carrier in a similar fashion as a sea based carrier. Once "landed" the engines are replaced with rocket motors and refueled. While this swap happens, the carrier rises to around 150,000 feet.

Upon atmospheric departure, the plane has a couple assist rockets to get it up to speed that return to the earth once spent. The runway would be equipped with a maglev launcher similar to the steam launcher of sea based carriers. This launch would be directly into the upper jet stream. While the plane continues to accelerate, it uses the air for lift until the air is too thin, but it still uses the air for what I call "velocity sail effect." The plane would surf until air drag would be almost non-existent, but with this known, as the drag drops, the acceleration increases proportionally. Once at close to 62 miles, the assist rockets jettison, and the planes own engines take over for the last push to low orbit, where there is a refueling station. They refuel, detach the now unnecessary wing structure, and continue to wherever they are going in earth orbit.

Upon re-entry, the plane would again refuel, reattach the wing structure, and then participate in a de-orbit burn slowing to a speed low enough for re-entry to not be very hot at all, and fly back to the airport.

The entire system would be developed to carry loads that are the same as an average container like used in modern shipping; roughly 25,000 lbs. Anything you wanted to send to orbit would be built and packaged in modules and storage vessels. The idea of launching the vehicle that goes to Mars from the top of a huge rocket is just stupid and unnecessary. One of the major expenses of shaping space vehicles out of carbon fiber is hardening the carbon fiber in an autolathe. I was reading a few years ago about a new process of hardening shaped carbon fiber by electric discharge plasma. It seems nothing ever came of the process that was discovered by some university lab. So, there's progress to be made, on reducing the cost per square foot of space durable carbon fiber. But instead Musk leaps back 50 years. SMH

In order to auto lathe Carbon Fiber you have to have a vacuum oven bigger than the vehicle you're making. There's only a few of them in the whole world. Generally people making space craft or aircraft rent the auto lathe for a day from the company that owns and operates the autolathe. So it costs about a million dollars or more to rent it for 1 day. So that's one of the major expenses of working with carbon fiber on large craft. If this electric plasma discharge process was developed to an extent that it was utile, then maybe Musk could make spacecraft in carbon fiber at less cost.

Thanks for your posts. Just found your channel. 30+ years ago I was reading every new collaboration of Larry Niven & Jerry Pournelle; was pretty stoked about their persistent efforts organizing a group of folks of various disciplines meeting to work up thoughtful proposals and concepts addressing the practical commercialization of "space." (Seems like there needs to be some neologism for the "nothingness" of the interplanetary/intergalactic regions...) It seems there's a real value to omnivorous reading... some folks focus on some narrow set of problems and spend decades absorbing data, formulae, test result tables, and hypotheses to make sense of – and Master – that field. But often, an enthusiastic and persistent outsider will bypass the "blind spots" that seem to plague the specialists in many fields, maybe from being too close to things, or they get so familiar and comfortable with their own toolsets, they stop putting emphasis on finding new ways to view the data. (And that by itself seems to really ꟼ¡$$ off the folks embedded in a specialized field!)
Early on, NASA's mission in many ways was to explore exotic materials, fabrication techniques, and applications, without always making cost/benefit equations the limiting factor, because history has shown so often that later, economies-of-scale bring costs down to acceptable levels. That seems not to have happened yet w carbon-composite fabrication. Thanks for Taking the time to work up this review.

stainless steel comes in so many grades. but one positive benefit of stainless is that not only is it tens of times better at coping with heat/cold contrasts and melting points, not only is it tens of times cheaper to produce in terms of material cost, but the time saving is also a major benefit..... but the best thing about using real stainless steel, is that many higher grades of stainless steels are NON MAGNETIC, and like aluminium, does not spark with friction. (yes, i know some of you will grab your expensive pots and pans and your fridge magnets will stick to them,,,,,,,but i can assure you, high quality stainless is harder than your pots and pans made of stainless steel, and high quality stainless has zero magnetic properties. this is a huge bonus for aircraft/orbiters/spacecraft.
(and finally, a dig at china, some will know what i mean, stainless steel is made with a mixture of steel, nickle and sometimes chrome depending on the grade of steel required......ALUMINIUM IS NOT STAINLESS STEEL CHINA.......................STOP SELLING ALUMINIUM PRODUCTS AS STAINLESS STEEL)
for those not in the know, china grades aluminium as stainless steel confusingly, just because it doesn't rust. .....and because of translations of metallurgy terms calling stainless steel an 'alloy" (alloy means mixture of two or more metals) and aluminium also being called alloy......but very different metals. literally chalk and cheese are more similar in composition than aluminium and stainless steel, which is an alloy. but yeah, china will sell you an aluminium item and by their laws and standards, are allowed to call it stainless steel.

My main concern about a trip to Mars is not the ship: It's how they expect to survive while on Mars, and how they will replenish, whether it be for a permanent colony, or a return trip.
I've heard they want to make fuel on Mars. I wonder how they plan to set up the industry for that, which must include transportation of raw materials, resource extraction, and many other details which are trivial on Earth, but potentially stupendous efforts in the effective vacuum of Mars. You can't just pressurize Martian atmosphere and expect to get breathable air, after all. I'm not willing to bet anyone's life on the actual availability of water, materials to source oxygen and other essentials for air, and foodstocks replenishment. You can't expect even hundreds of tons of payload to carry enough to keep the crew (colonists?) alive for years, much less psychologically stable.

I think they need to send multiple automated cargo ships ahead, with packaging capable of surviving bad landings--there are bound to be a couple of those--and re-usable rocket shells that can be used for temporary housing when the manned missions arrive. I'm also pretty sure they'll want smelting capability, and will want to have underground facilities, even if they're only going to be there for a few months.

If you factor in the cheaper cost of the rocket, we can expect to build more rockets for the same cost as one rocket using composite. I know the number are not right, Lets just assume they are. If a composite rocket cost 600m to build and Stainless cost 6m to build. That would be 60 rocket for the cost of one. Being that stainless is a much faster process to build, lets assume that you can build a composite rocket in say 10 units ( this can be days, weeks or what ever you want ) and stainless steel takes 1 unit.  You can now build 10 rockets in the time it takes to build one composite rocket. Being that stainless steel is a much faster process and does not require the extensive requirements as composite, You could have more than one location building rockets with much more ease than say composite. Now that you have the ability to build a lot of rockets at a faster and cheaper rate.  You can now deliver payloads of up to 100 tons, This means you can ship off more rockets to mars at much faster rates. We know that the trip can take 150-300 days ( shorter depending on speed and other factors ) There are 21 active launch pads world wide while 3 of them have ever launched humans. You can launch 60 rockets on a time loop so that a rocket lands say every few days or every week. Thus dropping off loads after loads of stuff to mars. Some day Space Truckers will be a real thing and we will see rocket launches every day. Space stations will be massive and Mars travel will be available to pretty much anyone who can afford it.

When spaceX was marketing their rockets to be made out of Carbon, I thought: "I don't trust this; is this really the best choice, or did they go for a material that sounds cool?"
12:06 "60 times cheaper to manufacture" Ehm, nope... If the material is cheap it doesn't mean it's cheap to manufacture. Some metals are easy to weld, some are hard to weld, some things can only be cut with a special ultrahard saw. etc. The manufacturing costs depends on the processing (bending, cutting, welding, glueing)
And in Aerospace there simply is no such thing as a 60 times cheaper material. A material that's 10% stronger at the same weight can (in some cases) double your profitability. "60 times cheaper" is not how it works, period.
Here is an example to show why: if a certain rocket can lift up with 100tons of weight, and that 100 tons consists of 75 tons of fuel, 22 tons of it's structure and 3 tons of payload; and then you take that rocket and make the structure of the rocket with a material that's 10% stronger, then you could theoretically (if you really oversimplify it) make the structure 10% lighter. Then you still have a rocket that can still lift up 100 tons, and the fuel is still 75 tons, but the structure now weighs 20 tons, so you have 5 tons left for the payload. So the max mass of the satellite you can take with you went from 3 to 5 tons...
If a rocket engine has a lower efficiency, and it wastes more fuel into heat but it has more power, then you can still have a more efficient rocket. Here is why: let's say I make a rocket engine with an efficiency of 100%, it turns 100% of the chemical energy into thrust, but my rocket engine produces just as much thrust as the weight of the rocket, then it means my rocket will just hover in one spot and not lift up. Then my buddy makes a rocket engine that's 10% efficient, but it produces a thrust that's 5 times as much as the weight of the rocket, then he will lift up and accelerate upwards with almost 40m/s².
Simple conclusion: just don't fall for marketing wank. These numbers mean nothing. No, really, absolutely nothing, if you don't know all the details. Especially if you are talking about a reusable rocket where fatigue comes into play, which is a major factor of the cost. If something is strong but unreliable, you need extra strengthening or other fixes to take care of that. These fixes can cost you way more than you've saved in the first place. I'm not saying stainless that moving to steel is a bad choice, because I had my doubts about carbon in the first place; I'm just saying this 60 times cheaper material can make a rocket both cheaper and more expensive, it depends on the implementation, it's all in the details.

Small criticism: Please remain consistent with the comparison of units. When you compared the price of Carbon Fiber Composites to Stainless Steel, you used KG, but it would have been more useful to use dollar-per-yield strength, even if that number changed on temperature.

I say as long as the rocket performs then the compromise is good.  I'd hope that by increasing the durability and longevity of the rocket and reducing it's complexity they will be able to either retain roughly the same payload, or at the very least build more rockets to carry multiple smaller payloads at once, but however it's done so long as the BFR/BFStarship performs the task it was designed for than the compromise is doing it's job, that being to advance the project and help in it's completion.  Obviously reducing the structural cost of the rocket that dramatically will be a huge step towards increasing the number produced, especially if the material (steel) is common (which it is).  It means that any factory that can turn out large thin steel plates could take on a contract to build some of the rocket parts, reducing the need for specialist manufacturing and further lowering costs.  One of the major stumbling blocks of rocketry is how specialized and expensive it is to build a rocket, so if the Starship project can at least partially fix that problem it will have overcome one of the global problems with rocketry in general.  Carbon composites are great for a lot of things but so far as I know they still don't have such a broad range of properties that they can replace every material effectively, and as their cost attests the facilities for mass producing them are still no match for the steel industry.  I'd think of them more for things like crew capsules, space station habitat module shells, or reenforcement for other structural materials, stuff which needs to be strong and light but also used sparingly and not in environments where they'll be exposed to lots of thermal shocking.

At 7:39 "soak up the heat like the tiles on the space shuttle" is not correct. Those tiles were designed to do just the opposite: not soak up the heat. This meant the heat could not be transfered into the aluminum skin and had to stay in the air.

No, it's not the same type of steel that you use on pots and what you call "high end" cooktops. There are many different kinds of blends of stainless steel alloys.

There are types of stainless steel that is extra hard but brittle and prone to corrosion, that are commonly used for sharp knives. There are types of stainless steel that are corrosion resistant that are commonly used for containers that are supposed to store reactive chemicals. SAE 316 is one such example. There are also so called "invar" steel alloys that expands/contracts negligibly compared to other stainless steel alloys, commonly used in scientific instruments for reliability.

Ordinary cookware commonly uses a cheap stainless steel alloy that is more resistant to corrosion than iron and is safe for cooking, i.e. it is focused on health safety which means that it doesn't contain lead or any other poisonous metals that can leach into the food upon contact with the metal. Now, most SS alloys are safe for cooking, but this is obviously a priority for SS used in cookware.

I'm not sure Elon meant coldforming AT cryo. At least that's not something I've ever heard of before. I think it was meant as normal coldforming of steel sheets which just means forming the metal at temperatures below recrystallization temps.
The forming of the metal increases the amounts of dislocations inside the lattice structure. Dislocations hinder the movement of atoms along the lattice structure which in effect increases the strength of the material. If the metal was over recrystallization temperature, the dislocations would disappear as the crystal reforms.
So the problem with cold forming is that the metal gets harder and harder and thus harder to form, especially if you have to apply stress over a long roller. I guess that is what Dawson engineered and can handle now.

The cryogenic part I think is referring to cryogenic hardening. So after hardening you cool the metal to cryogenic temperatures. This helps transform rests of austenite to martensite and furthermore creates a high density of gaps in the lattice structure which can be filled with special carbides that form during a subsequent tempering process. This further increases strength even beyond martensite. This is a fairly new technique and I'm not sure it has been done to parts as big as rocket fuselages yet.

I actually think using steel or even aluminium is a smarter choice for reusable rockets. Unlike metals, carbon composite parts fail catastrophically without a lot of forewarning since they do not really deform before breaking. They just get not visible micro fractures and suddenly they fail. Metals on the other hand will deform first which gives them a little bit of extra time to work and hopefully fix before a part breaks. So if a rocket lands an inspection should relatively easily find parts that are about to fail and can be replaced preemptively.

Disclaimer: That said I'm not a metallurgist either. So my knowledge is limited to the material science class I took during studying engineering at university, which was not my personal focus.

Starting at 8:55, you say that since stainless steel (SS) is so shiny it will actually "reflect a good bit of that radiant heat away instead of absorbing it". Not sure what you are talking about. SS has a very low infrared (IR) emissivity ("low e") which means it does a poor job of radiating heat. Thus, if a surface is getting hot (due to, say atmospheric heating during re-entry, for example), giving it a lower emissivity will cause it to get hotter since it can't radiate off the heat as well as a "high e" (e.g. black) surface (per the Stefan-Boltzman law, heat is radiated proportional to emissivity). Now, if your SS surface is not the one being heated but some other surface nearby is being heated, then making your surface low e (like SS) will help because the low e means it also is a poor absorber of heat (per Kirchoff's law of radiation, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirchhoff%27s_law_of_thermal_radiation). This why extremely shiny surfaces (like highly polished SS), which have low e, are used as thermal shields; see, for example, https://ws680.nist.gov/publication/get_pdf.cfm?pub_id=914418 where they are trying to used highly polished SS to shield something from a nearby hot surface.

So, if SpaceX is using SS on the outer surface of the rocket, it's going to get hot due to atmospheric heating (which happens independent of the surface finish), and making it low e means it would get hotter than making it high e (black). See for example, pg 184 of https://www.nasa.gov/centers/johnson/pdf/584728main_Wings-ch4b-pgs182-199.pdf which talks about the heat shields on the Space Shuttle, where it states "Several types of Thermal Protection System materials were used on the Orbiter. These materials included tiles, advanced flexible reusable surface insulation, reinforced carbon-carbon, and flexible reusable surface insulation. All of these materials used high-emissivity coatings to ensure the maximum rejection of incoming convective heat through radiative heat transfer." The last sentence is the key. And note that the space shuttle heat shields are all black (which is high e).

Anyway, not sure what you are trying to say here, so might to re-phrase it. Bottom line is: black/matte colors are good for rejecting heat, (they are actually other non-black surface finishes that are also high e, like optical solar reflectors (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_solar_reflector), but let's keep it simple) and "shiny" metal like polished SS is the opposite and hence terrible at rejecting heat.

About the same payload capacity as the Saturn-V is a good number. Energia is close, and the Shuttle stack does this too, but less of it is useful payload.

There are innumerable potential near-term applications for ~100 tons to LEO. And it's smaller than we should be pushing rocket design for. Sea Dragon was to be simple steel 2STO for ~500 tons to LEO.
There were lots of post-Apollo "Nova" and some during the studies about SSPS systems for which ~300 tons might have been the starting point for 1 or 2 STO designs.
Rockwell Star-Raker SSTO plane was for 100 tons, in a standard cargoplane or flat-bed sized load arrangement.

There were never any severe technical problems about these. As with the Saturn-V and NERVA engines, they represented an embarrassing excess of capability to an agency and government which had no ambitions post-Apollo at all.

Something you missed was mass vs enclosed volume vs material strength. To make a rocket the size of the Starship with aluminum, the metal would have to be quite a bit thicker than when built with stainless steel. That could negate aluminum's lighter weight per unit of volume. Carbon fiber composite could still come in lighter than aluminum or stainless steel for the big rocket, but its thickness would have to more than using aluminum. Given the cost and complexity, carbon fiber composite's advantages VS stainless steel rapidly declines as the size of the rocket increases.

Volume increases x3 as size goes up while surface area only increases x2, which roughly equals the rate that the amount of material required goes up with rocket size. Thus for smaller rockets like the Falcon 9 or Blue Origin carbon fiber composite saves a lot more weight over metal per unit of rocket volume than it does on a big freaking rocket. At some point in rocket size it's likely that carbon fiber composite would have to weigh more than stainless steel for the rocket to be able to support its own weight on the pad plus handle the stresses of flight.

I can definitely see why Space X is leaning toward Stainless Steel for many of its applications.

In the Oil & Gas Exploration and Production Industry areas I am associated with (i.e., Prudhoe Bay, Endicott Island, North Star Island, Milne Point, Point Thompson, Badami, Lisburne, and Kuparuk Oil Fields) of Northern Alaska - which has over 77,000 miles of piping within these fields - and of which - all these separate oil fields feed through individual and / or combined cross country pipelines to eventually bring the oil and gas products to one metering skid and then across the Spine Road into Pump Station #1 - which is at the very head of the Trans Alaska Pipeline - we use Stainless Steel (SS) Piping, Elbows, Valves and other components in many, many areas we do not want to have to Inspect and / or replace as often as the High Carbon Steel (CS) Piping and components normally used throughout the rest of the fields.

The newer facilities and piping applications use a lot more SS than the older areas of the different fields, too - especially in areas that previous Inspection Cycle History in other portions of the different oil fields noted that high CS pipe used for the same or a similar purpose was much more likely to corrode and / or fail faster, and therefore, be replaced a lot more often, than SS Material used for the same application. Therefore, the High CS pipe soaked up a lot more of your Inspection & Maintenance Dollars in particular applications and/or production areas than SS pipe used for the same purpose.

Meaning - SS Material was much more cost effective over time in certain applications and piping environments than High CS Materials.

So in summary, though the SS material in our oil field applications was originally much more expensive (which is also changing - the more you use, the less the cost over time) - the benefits of longevity in the Arctic Conditions, lack of corrosion in areas of piping where the contents was known to be very corrosive in High CS piping, and - in many cases - the SS Material did not even require insulation (a major cost in maintaining the longevity of High CS Piping in Arctic Conditions) - made SS very cost competitive. Depending on what is moving through the pipe, the high pressures (sometimes higher the 4,000 psi) and heat the piping in an area had to deal with, along with a very demanding outside environment (sometimes less than -65 mid-winter and above 90 F in summer) besides the wet conditions, metal eating "Bugs" in the contents (actually metal corroding enzymes produced by certain types of bacteria present in raw oil and gas at certain temperatures and pressures being brought to the surface and transported to initial Separation Facilities) all made SS components for certain oil field conditions very, very cost effective.

Just avoid SS applications that have a high Salt content.

And yes - we used a lot of WD40. :O)

other advantages of Stainless Steel over carbon composite:  durability and ease of maintenance.  Stainless steel is much more isotropic compared to carbon composite structures, meaning its strength is much more uniform in all directions.  Whack the side of a stainless steel rocket and you may dent it.  Do the same with carbon composite and if the direction of loading wasn't one considered in the design phase, it might just fail.   Further, because stainless steel is ductile material, it will more likely dent and stretch instead of crack or split, meaning it is more likely to be able to be repaired instead of having to be patched or replaced.  Also, the fatigue life of stainless steel is well understood.  Not so much for carbon composites, which haven't been around as long.  If you cyclically load something, like you would pressurizing and flying a rocket, its fairly well known how that would affect stainless steel.  Not so for carbon composite.  Finally, if you are concerned about a flaw in the material, stainless steel is easy to visually inspect for things like cracks, either by naked eye or dye penetrant.  In critical cases, its also easily x-rayed.  Its much harder to spot developing flaws in carbon composite.

Great video! Just a couple of things to note;
First, cold forming is just shaping a material without heating it up, no need to cool it down to cryogenic temperatures. Think like bending a hair pin.
Second, cold forming steel actually increases its strength because you're adding energy to the material and takes all that energy and deforms plastically. Plastic deformation is when you bend a material beyond the elastic point, I.e. the point where it won't return to its original shape. Think again that hair pin, bending it is easy but unbending it needs a bit more energy to do, you feel it stiffening up.
I haven't read up on what SpaceX is doing, but I'd assume they're cold forming it to increase its strength. It's easier to shape steel when it's heated up, but depending on how you cool it down, it would have the same strength as before shaping.
The problem with cold forming is that your essentially damaging the material to make it stiffer. But stiffening it would make it more prone to cracking. So depending on the application you can either hot form or cold form a material.
Also I should note that I am a metallurgist, you pronounced it correctly the first time 😁

We also have to remember that Carbon composites are new and the fatigue issues are not thoroughly understood.  We have used steel for generations and have a complete understanding of how it ages and reacts - Which for reuse ability is a very good thing.

The SR71 was almost completely made of titanium and the leading edges and some certain other parts (won't say) were made of inconel x, the stuff was pretty much designed for that plane.. The leading edges hit well over 1000 degrees during high speed flight at over Mach 3. (remember officially it can hit "Mach 3+") I used to have a substitute teacher that was a rear seater in one and he said that while he couldn't say actual numbers it is way higher than that.. that, in the early days, after doing their mission they were given free reign to figure out just what the plane could do. He told me a story about how one day they were somewhere in Asia and after coming back west they went up to 6 digits altitude and pitched it down slightly and went full power and traded altitude and Tons of JP7 for air speed and went "scary fast, and it still had more in her.. I think you could classify it as hypersonic.. we got bitched out for the scoring on the coating when we got back.." (officially hypersonic is Mach5+)

I think anything that will help Superheavy/Starship come into existence sooner, is good.  I wonder if it will just be Starship made out of SS, or Superheavy as well.  It would be unfortunate to significantly reduce the payload.  Superheavy will not be subjected to as high heat as Starship, and it's the larger piece so it seems that if you were to make that out of SS as well it would really cut into the payload.  Not all methods of producing composites results in waste, for example, the process shown in this video uses carbon fiber tow (string) wrapped around the mold.  This method doesn't produce much if any waste.  Waste comes when you use carbon fiber weave (flat sheets) and you have to cut out the shapes.  I can't wait till Elon puts out more information about the updated design.  Also keep in mind, This 1st version of Superheavy/Starship is just that, the 1st version.  It could make sense that they make this version to get it flying ASAP and then later on down the road still make the lighter carbon composite version with a higher payload.  Gwynne Shotwell has said in interviews that they are thinking of making even larger BFR's in the future.

When Sir Frank Whittle was building his prototype jet turbine engine in 1936 he was looking for a suitable material for his turbine. No alloy it seems was made that could withstand the high gas temperatures produced by the burners. He found his material in Sheffield. The cutlery that was marked Firth-Vickers Rex 78 (or was it Staybright) went into that turbine and allowed the first jet engine to run. (Yes, the first to run..not to fly - to run).

I think SpaceX are going to have huge problems with convincing NASA to crew-rate Starship. They've just gone through a huge amount of effort to do this for the much more conventional Crew Dragon. By comparison, for Starship:
* I don't think there is any way to escape a failing booster. I doubt that the Starship's engines can be fired while still attached to the booster, and even if they could it would take several seconds (i.e. too long) to start them, and they'd provide insufficient acceleration. The Shuttle tragically taught us what can happen when you can't escape malfunctioning boosters.
* For Starship, the rockets are safety critical during landing
* The active cooling is safety critical during reentry
* Large size is likely to bring various additional safety concerns.

If NASA isn't convinced, could they still launch from USA facilities with non-NASA astronauts? Do the FAA (aviation administration) and NTSB (transport safety) have any say?

Some information I would like to add to the topic:

There are a variety of carbon composites and each vary in their properties. I believe the composites talked about in the video are what is known as PMCs, or polymer matrix composites and as Tim mentioned, these do degrade at lower temperatures due to oxidation, cracking, and debonding, which ultimately weakens the bonding of the materials. There are another class of carbon composites called CMCs, or ceramic matrix composites. These materials can last up to 4000F before oxidation occurs, provided their is a good coating around the matrix itself, but that depends on the type of fiber being used. I won't delve too much into that and just stick with Carbon based CMCs. Thus they don't have the limitations of 301 Stainless Steel, which has a melting point of 2500-2600F.

The type of cooling that Tim talks about is called transpiration cooling and has been considered for a variety of uses for a little while now. The main reason why you don't see it employed often is because its considered a waste of mass on aircraft. The sole purpose of the fluid being used for transpiration is to be carried off of the aircraft. Other options of cooling currently being investigated for the purpose of cooling are using heat pipes or circulating fuel/other fluid around the aircraft. Each has drawbacks and advantages.

Finally, just because stainless steel can survive reentry doesn't mean it shouldn't have heat shields. The main purpose of BFR is to be reusable and that isn't necessarily possible if the ship looks like the photo presented within the video. Heat shields aren't only for protection of the vehicular structure either. There are many subsystems that must be below a certain temperature to perform and in addition, it isn't comfortable for humans to sit in temperatures anywhere near what the surface undergoes so they also limit the temperature penetration within the cabin of the vehicle.

If they are going to weld the Starship and Superheavy stainless steel they should use 304L or 316L to prevent sensitization and the formation of intergranular corrosion cracking due to welding and them operating these vehicles on the coast near a salt water environment. Even stainless steel can rust especially due to chloride corrosion and welds/joints corrode the fastest due to chromium carbide precipitation in regular stainless like 200 and 300 standard stainless with higher carbon contents. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intergranular_corrosion#Sensitization_effect

One thing you didn't mention, aluminum alloys have limited stress cycles- they always fatigue, and because of the high stresses in rocketry, the lifecycle is not very high at all. For example the Space Shuttle main tanks, they had 6 pressurisation cycles, and then they would have to throw the tank away. There's not the same limit with stainless steel, potentially a stainless steel rocket has enormously longer life. But it's been much more expensive initially to work, so it hasn't been widely used.

Great Video - here are some thoughts:

Ditching the carbon fiber tanks seems a good idea to reduce the risk (and is most likely the driving factor). Making huge things out of carbon fiber is REALY hard to do and no one realy did it. We are getting there at some point, but the time does not seem to be here atm.

Your price comparison is quite unfair since they are not going to use household stainless steel. They have to use austenite steel (these are the ones not getting brittle when cooled down - regular steel will just shatter) with high chrome and nickel contents wich are quite costly. I guess it's still going to be cheaper than carbon fiber (due to the high manufacturing cost of CF), but not the huge difference some may expect.

Steel is also good for the BFR because of it's size - I am very certain, that steel would not be a good option for smaller rockets.

The only real contender for steel would be a titanium alloy - but these do have their own share of problems at temperatures above ~800°C. It's either going to oxidize or (due to the lack of an atmosphere since methane is bleeding out of the structure) hydrogen from the methane is going to diffuse into the titanium - and that's even worse. I still think the tanks could be lighter (but certainly not cheaper) if made out of titanium, but I am also certain that SpaceX has run the numbers and came to the best conclusion with the system as a whole in mind.

I think the biggest factor for using stainless over carbon fiber is that stainless is easy to build with and repair. If your ship was damaged by a micro meteor or something or damaged after landing on mars, with a stainless ship you'd just use a hammer and a spare plate and weld a patch over the hole. With carbon fiber you can't really do that. Also for engineering carbon fiber is not isotropic like steel is. This makes designing the structure to be manufacturable about 100x easier.  Bottom line, stainless is an easier material to work with, it's cheaper, has similar performance characteristics to carbon fiber where it matters, and it's shiny.

I am old enough to remember the early "space race" rocketry and was living in San Diego when the Atlas was still going through development. I also followed the X-15 flights avidly. I knew back then that the Atlas was very different from its cousins, the Thor (which became the basis for the Delta series) and the Titan missiles which were made from Aluminum.
While I understood that the aluminum construction of the Titan was rather heavy and similar to what became the Saturn V, itself an outgrowth of the german V-2 construction techniques, I had to wonder for quite a few years how the Thor/Delta managed to have such a smooth outer skin, while corrugations and riveted panels composed the the others. Sometime near the end of the 20th century the method used for the Thor was declassified, and the extremely expensive machining of internal wavy channels that rendered 0.5" thick aluminum tank walls into very thin, but very strong tanks was revealed.
In some ways, the Atlas and the Russian R-7 stories also tell the story of the relative strengths and weaknesses of each country's early ICBM efforts. The original design for the Atlas program would have had the same "throw weight" and a similar arrangement of booster engines and sustainers all lit on the ground that both rockets used. The R-7 of course became the Soyuz because the Russians could not afford to start over when hydrogen nuclear weapon size shrank significantly for both programs. So they went ahead with the bigger rocket. The Alas was revised downward, possibly allowing for the stainless balloon structure, or at least allowing it to be much thinner for the same capability.

While during that period, post sputnik, where the Russians seemed to be one step ahead of us every time we announced a new effort to utilize space for something not related to weaponry, something more practical for human civilization's continued existence, the Atlas did one amazing thing its stainless balloon tank technology allowed for. With no payload atop it and only a small radio transmitter and tape player shoehorned into one of its side fairings, in December 1958 it lofted itself entirely into orbit (minus the booster engines, but the whole tank assembly) with a message of peace and goodwill from President Eisenhower to the world. For the first time we had orbited more mass,(and had nearly achieved a single stage to orbit) than the Soviets could with their stronger, but heavier missile.
Of course, the Soyuz booster system was also more robust, as we know so well today.

WD-40 works very well but most people don't realize it works very poorly as a lubricant. It is a penetrating oil not a lubricating oil. SpaceX's leaky heat shield isn't a new idea and it's actually quite well proven. The SR71 Blackbird used to leak fuel out of it's leading edges to cool the aircraft at hyper sonic speeds. For a long time they claimed when asked about the leaking that it was an unintentional effect of how the plane was built and that the leaking would stop when the aircraft heated up in flight, but it has since come out this was a lie. In truth the fuel didn't ever stop leaking, it was actually an active heat shield that worked pretty much that same as SpaceX is planning for Starship.

I only see one big problem with stainless. You should also look at the thermal expansion.  I've worked with stainless welding before.  It moves quite a bit with temperature changes, and on something that big it would have to shrink by a few inches when cryogenic.  That will cause issues with seams trying to pull apart or causing cracks.  The underlying structure may buckle.  When it expands with heat, it will wrinkle which causes uneven airflow (and hot spots).  Then there's the crazy condensation in Florida, those tiny holes will likely get plugged with ice.  Yes it can be forced out and it will melt somewhat, but cryogenic methane will refreeze it. That also may cause uneven temps on reentry.

The only thing that doesn't really add up is dust. Whether is the Moon or Mars, the surface dust is incredibly fine and sticky. Having a layer of dust on the rocket surface might: i) Reduce the reflectivity, decreasing the heat radiated away. ii) Clog a substantial fraction of the pores, compromising the fuel bleed off. These two effects can be quite problematic for a Starship trying an atmospheric re-entry after a Moon or Mars landing. I wonder how SpaceX is addressing the problem (if this is indeed a problem)...

Another advantage of steel is fatigue life. As long as you keep the material within the regime of elastic deformation and stay out of plastic deformation (ie do not exceed the yield strength), fatigue life is indefinite. This isn't the case with aluminium alloys - it's why airframes have an "hours limit". For expendable rockets this isn't really an issue, but for a reusable system it will become one.

The cost per kg comparison is actually an aggregate and in case of carbon fiber it hides several issues, associated with its manufacturing. CF is yet another example of cheap raw materials being converted into ridiculously expensive end product. The main component in this cost aggregate is actually time. Weaving CF and then curing it takes hideously long... and yet you have no guarantee that the end-product will be up to specs. It also scales up really badly, any structural changes affecting your rocket's dimensions will basically render your production line scrap-worthy.
CF doesn't really fit SpaceX development model as it works against their idea of fast and frequent design iterations.

As for transpiration cooling, SpaceX is already using it in first stages of Block 5 variant, in which water is used to cool the base-plate of thrust structure.

When Elon posted his explanation of why they did this a couple weeks back, I loved the sentence in there where he says he had to convince his own engineers of these things. The cost savings alone is a game changer for Starship. With a Falcon 9 costing almost $99 million (weight * $180 / kg, yes, not exact as not everything is made of carbon fiber but this illustrates the point), swapping that for stainless it would cost only $1.6 million. $99 million vs $1.6 million. Yeah... that alone completely alters the equation for rocket manufacture. Throw in the weight and cost savings for a heat shield and it's even better. I had missed his tweet about the cold forming of stainless... but the ease of doing that with stainless is another solid win. And how utterly simple it is to get your hands on the material and work with it... there is literally zero downside to this. And once you look at the math and physical properties of it all it really becomes a no brainer. They aren't really compromising here at all... every single aspect of this is firmly in the win column. Cheaper, easier, actually stronger, less weight in the end, etc.

Plus, you're right... a shiny chromed out rocket is going to look unbelievably awesome. Especially with those triple fins. I always see people posting how Elon just hires smart people to be around him. Everyone always forgets that he himself has double degrees in physics and economics and that he was literally the designer of the Falcon 1 since they couldn't afford to hire a dedicated rocket designer.
